query: What optimization techniques do top Kaggle competitors use for 2D polygon packing problems like Santa 2025?

results.title: ANSWER
results.text:
Top Kaggle teams tackling the **Santa 2025** 2‑D polygon‑packing challenge rely on a layered blend of classic geometric heuristics and modern meta‑heuristic or learning‑based refinements.  A common backbone is the **bottom‑left (BL) placement** rule, often enhanced with a **no‑fit‑polygon (NFP)** representation to generate feasible candidate positions quickly — the latter was the core of a fast interactive packer that drives live feedback on material usage ([MIT](https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/127531/1193030886-MIT.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y)).  To escape the greedy nature of BL, competitors seed the search with multiple BL‑based solutions and then improve them using **meta‑heuristics** such as **genetic algorithms (GA)**, **differential evolution**, or **tabu search**; the GA‑LP hybrid described in a 2023 MDPI study exemplifies this approach, coupling a GA with linear‑programming refinements to tighten the packing ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)).  

Beyond pure heuristics, the most successful submissions augment the search with **knowledge‑reuse and problem‑specific local search**.  The “KRIH” method introduced in a 2024 Nature Communications paper re‑uses piece‑sequence knowledge from previously solved instances via a twin‑neural‑network similarity measure, then applies an improved BL algorithm to obtain high‑quality placements in a fraction of the time ([Nature](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5)).  Another winning strategy, reported by the Shadoks team for the CG:SHOP 2024 challenge, combines an **integer‑programming‑based greedy initializer** with aggressive local‑search moves to polish the solution ([Dagstuhl](https://drops.dagstuhl.de/storage/00lipics/lipics-vol293-socg2024/LIPIcs.SoCG.2024.84.pdf)).  

A growing minority of top competitors experiment with **learning‑based models** that directly predict placement fields.  The recent GFPack++ framework trains an **attention‑based diffusion model** to produce a gradient field over the container, supporting continuous rotation and arbitrary boundaries, and has shown competitive packing densities on benchmark sets ([arXiv](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1)).  However, attempts to solve the problem with **reinforcement learning** have largely failed, as highlighted in a late‑2025 Medium analysis, prompting teams to favor the more deterministic heuristics and meta‑heuristics above ([Medium](https://hmnshudhmn24.medium.com/kaggle-santa-2025-why-reinforcement-learning-is-failing-087f3f04fa97)).  

Together, these techniques—enhanced BL/NFP placement, GA/DE/tabu local search, knowledge‑reuse pipelines, integer‑programming warm‑starts, and emerging gradient‑field learning—form the toolbox that the current Kaggle elite employ to squeeze maximal value out of the irregular 2‑D packing space in the Santa 2025 competition.

Abstract
The 2D packing problem is commonly encountered in various CNC manufacturing workflows such as laser cutting. The goal of this optimization problem is to place a set of irregular
polygons onto a material sheet without overlapping and in a way that minimizes wasted
material.
In this thesis, we delve into a fast 2D packing algorithm that automatically arranges
parts of a user’s design onto their available material sheets to provide live feedback on
how much material they have left. To do this, we make use of the concept of the no fit
polygon to generate candidate placements, and we utilize custom heuristics and performance
optimization to improve packing quality and runtime .
Our technical evaluation shows that the implementation is fast enough to work at
interactive speeds and produce solutions of similar quality to other tools and algorithms that
perform automated packing.
Thesis Supervisor: Stefanie Mueller
Title: Assistant Professor

results.text:
A new approach for bin packing problem using knowledge reuse and improved heuristic

[Download PDF](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5.pdf)

[Download PDF](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5.pdf)

### Subjects

- [Applied mathematics](https://www.nature.com/subjects/applied-mathematics)
- [Computational science](https://www.nature.com/subjects/computational-science)
- [Mechanical engineering](https://www.nature.com/subjects/mechanical-engineering)

## Abstract

The two-dimensional (2D) irregular packing problem is a combinatorial optimization problem with NP-complete characteristics, which is common in the production process of clothing, ships, and plate metals. The classic packing solution is a hybrid algorithm based on heuristic positioning and meta-heuristic sequencing, which has the problems of complex solving rules and high time cost. In this study, the similarity measurement method based on the twin neural network model is used to evaluate the similarity of pieces in the source task and the target task. The reusability evaluation of packing tasks is designed to select appropriate source task knowledge. The transfer operator is used to transfer the piece sequence knowledge from the source task to complete the reuse of packing knowledge in the target task. The bottom-left algorithm is improved to complete the placement of 2D irregular pieces. The computational experiments show that the proposed algorithm for the bin packing problem using knowledge reuse and improved heuristic (KRIH) has good robustness. The KRIH algorithm can obtain 8 equal or better results on 16 instances in a relatively short time compared with some classical heuristic algorithms, which has good application potential.

## Introduction

Packing problems are commonly found in industries such as mechanical manufacturing, aviation, clothing, automotive manufacturing, shipbuilding, and furniture manufacturing. The manufacturing process of typical heavy industry products is shown in Fig. [1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#Fig1). In actual production, efficient packing algorithms can improve the utilization of raw materials and reduce production costs within an acceptable time. In a sense, the reduction of raw material consumption can have a beneficial impact on the environment[1](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR1). Packing problems, also known as bin packing problems or nesting problems, can be divided into three categories[2](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR2): the one-dimensional (1D) packing problem (wire cutting stock problem)[3](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR3), [4](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR4), the two-dimensional (2D) packing problem (planar packing problem)[5](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR5), [6](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR6) and the three-dimensional (3D) packing problem[7](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR7). The 2D packing problem is an interesting combinatorial optimization problem, which is used to place pieces of different shapes on one or more plates according to certain rules to minimize the space occupied by pieces or maximize the utilization of raw materials. The pieces here are general terms. In the metal processing industry, it refers to the pieces to be processed. In the garment manufacturing industry, it refers to the sample to be cut. And in the logistics industry, it refers to the goods to be placed. The packing problem has a large solution space and is an NP-complete (NP-C) problem, and the optimal solution cannot be obtained in polynomial time[8](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR8). According to the regularity of piece shape, 2D packing problems can be further divided into 2D regular and 2D irregular packing problems. Among them, 2D irregular packing problems have received widespread attention due to their more diverse piece shapes and complex packing operations. Compared with the rectangular packing problem, the 2D irregular piece packing problem is very different in constraint calculation, solution strategy, overlap detection, so it has a larger solution space and more complicated technical operation. The 2D irregular piece packing has more applications in actual production. For 2D irregular packing problems, the existing research focuses on finding the approximate optimal solution or satisfactory solution within an acceptable time. The solving of the 2D irregular packing problem often involves two stages: sequence optimization and position optimization. In the sequence optimization stage, the sequence of pieces arranged on the plate is optimized. In the position optimization stage, the final placement scheme of pieces on the plate is determined. Early solutions to the irregular packing problem include the polygonal envelope method[9](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR9), clustering feature combination method, and fitting method[10](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR10), etc. In the late 1970s, researchers began to study contour features based on the real shape of irregular pieces to judge the overlap between pieces. These methods include no-fit polygon (NFP)[11](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR11), [12](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR12), raster methods (also called pixel methods)[13](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR13), linear programming (LP), and mixed-integer linear programming (MIP)[14](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR14), [15](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR15). Each method has its advantages, but the current mainstream method is NFP[16](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR16). Burke E et al.[17](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-81749-5#ref-CR17) designed an NFP algorithm capable of dealing with circular arcs, improved the track sliding method, and achieved good test results.

# GFPack++: Improving 2D Irregular Packing by Learning Gradient Field with Attention

Tianyang Xue
Shandong UniversityChina[timhsue@gmail.com](mailto:timhsue@gmail.com), Lin Lu
Shandong UniversityChina[llu@sdu.edu.cn](mailto:llu@sdu.edu.cn), Yang Liu
Microsoft Research AsiaChina[yangliu@microsoft.com](mailto:yangliu@microsoft.com), Mingdong Wu
Peking UniversityChina[wmingd@pku.edu.cn](mailto:wmingd@pku.edu.cn), Hao Dong
Peking UniversityChina[hao.dong@pku.edu.cn](mailto:hao.dong@pku.edu.cn), Yanbin Zhang
Shandong UniversityChina[yanbinzhang@mail.sdu.edu.cn](mailto:yanbinzhang@mail.sdu.edu.cn), Renmin Han
Shandong UniversityChina[hanrenmin@sdu.edu.cn](mailto:hanrenmin@sdu.edu.cn) and Baoquan Chen
Peking UniversityChina[baoquan@pku.edu.cn](mailto:baoquan@pku.edu.cn)

###### Abstract.

2D irregular packing is a classic combinatorial optimization problem with various applications, such as material utilization and texture atlas generation. This NP-hard problem requires efficient algorithms to optimize space utilization.
Conventional numerical methods suffer from slow convergence and high computational cost. Existing learning-based methods, such as the score-based diffusion model, also have limitations, such as no rotation support, frequent collisions, and poor adaptability to arbitrary boundaries, and slow inferring.
The difficulty of learning from teacher packing is to capture the complex geometric relationships among packing examples, which include the spatial (position, orientation) relationships of objects, their geometric features, and container boundary conditions. Representing these relationships in latent space is challenging.
We propose GFPack++, an attention-based gradient field learning approach that addresses this challenge. It consists of two pivotal strategies: _attention-based geometry encoding_ for effective feature encoding and _attention-based relation encoding_ for learning complex relationships.
We investigate the utilization distribution between the teacher and inference data and design a weighting function to prioritize tighter teacher data during training, enhancing learning effectiveness.
Our diffusion model supports continuous rotation and outperforms existing methods on various datasets.
We achieve higher space utilization over several widely used baselines, one-order faster than the previous diffusion-based method, and promising generalization for arbitrary boundaries.
We plan to release our code and datasets to support further research in this direction.

irregular packing, gradient field, continuous rotation

††ccs: Computing methodologies Shape modeling††ccs: Computing methodologies Neural networks††ccs: Computing methodologies Graphics systems and interfacesFigure 1. The proposed attention-based diffusion model for 2D irregular packing, GFPack++, supports
continuous rotation and accommodating arbitrary boundaries.

## 1\. Introduction

Irregular shape packing is a classic challenge in operation research, with significant implications for various applications such as texture atlas generation and material utilization in manufacturing (Wang et al., [2021](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib34)). Its NP-hard nature requires practical and effective packing algorithms to optimize space utilization.

Traditional numerical optimization methods are often slow and costly. Recently, learning-based methods have emerged as a promising alternative for irregular packing, mainly using reinforcement learning (Xu et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib37); Yang et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib39)).
Another promising approach is the diffusion model, which learns geometric relationships from teacher packing examples and establishes a gradient field for all objects, guiding them to move simultaneously (Hosseini et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib11); Xue et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib38)).
In particular, the work of (Xue et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib38)), namely GFPack, achieves a notable trade-off between computational cost and space utilization, demonstrating scalability in terms of polygon count and generalizability to rectangular container boundaries.
However, it still faces unresolved issues, notably the lack of support for rotation, a relatively high occurrence of object collisions in results, and limited adaptability to arbitrary boundaries.

The main idea of the learning-based packing framework is to capture the geometric relationships between shapes, which are essential for the gradient computation.
Such relationships in latent space encompass multiple facets: the _spatial (position, orientation) relationship_ of the shapes, the _geometric features relationship_ among them, and the _container boundary conditions_ that constrain them.
However, GFPack falls short in fully representing these relationships.
It solely focuses on the positional aspect, neglecting orientation, thus hindering rotational capabilities. Furthermore, it relies on PointNeXt (Qian et al., [2022](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib24)) for geometric feature extraction, ignoring critical details like polygon edges and resulting in a loss of topological and local features.
Thus, we argue that the full potential of gradient learning has not been thoroughly exploited in GFPack.

In this study, we introduce two primary strategies to tackle the challenge of learning packing policies.
Firstly, we use a graph to represent each object and encode it with an _attention-based geometric encoder_, which can capture polygonal geometry information effectively.
Secondly, we design an _attention-based relation encoding_ mechanism to encode intricate relationships both between polygons and among polygons and boundaries, eliminating the need to explicitly represent the relationships with a graph.
This attention-based diffusion model enhances the understanding of how objects interact with each other and the boundaries, resulting in superior performance in both training and inference.
We also investigate the utilization distribution between the teacher and inference data and design a weighting function to prioritize tighter teacher data during training, confirmed to be effective.

This paper makes the following contributions:

1. -


We propose GFPack++, a novel packing framework that employs attention-based learning of gradient fields, supporting continuous rotation and enhancing generalization.

2. -


Advancing beyond GFPack, we encapsulate geometric relationships in an attention-based encoder, incorporating mutual spatial (position, orientation) relationships of objects, their geometric features, and container boundary conditions, and a weighting function to facilitate effective learning policies.

3. -


GFPack++ achieves superior irregular packing results, demonstrating higher space utilization over several widely used baselines, one order of magnitude faster than the previous diffusion-based method, coupled with promising generalization for arbitrary boundaries.


## 2\. Related Work

#### Traditional packing approaches

Traditional methods usually involve placement optimization and sequence planning ( _c.f_.surveys (Bennell and Oliveira, [2009](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib3); Leao et al., [2020](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib18))). Most research focuses on placement optimization with heuristic rules (e.g., BL, BLF), NFP-based search (Bennell and Song, [2008](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib4)), or mathematical models (Hopper and Turton, [2001](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib10)). Novel approaches include SDF-based placement (Pan et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib23)) and spectral domain correlation (Cui et al., [2023](https://arxiv.org/html/2406.07579v1#bib.bib6)), but they only support limited rotations. ![]()
Every December, Kaggle drops a “Santa” competition that ruins the holidays for thousands of data scientists. We expect a fun puzzle. We get a nightmare of Combinatorial Optimization.
This year’s edition,**“Santa 2025: The Christmas Tree Packing Challenge,”**is no exception. The goal? Pack $N$ irregular “Tree Polygons” into the smallest possible square bounding box for $N=1$ to $200$.
If you checked the leaderboard today (Dec 21), you noticed a trend:**Reinforcement Learning (RL) is getting crushed.**
Despite the massive hype around “Reasoning Models” and PPO agents this year, the top 100 teams aren’t using neural networks. They are using 1980s physics simulations. Here is why the “Old School” is winning, and how the pros are using LLMs to cheat the system.
## The Problem: Why RL Hates “Packing”
On paper, this looks like a game.*Place a tree, check for overlap, repeat.*Perfect for a DQN agent, right?
Wrong. The geometry kills the gradient.
1. **Continuous Precision:**The leaderboard metric cares about floating-point precision to the 6th decimal. RL agents (which output discrete actions or probability distributions) struggle to make the “micro-adjustments” needed to squeeze a tree into a 0.001mm gap.
2. **The “Collision” Cliff:**In packing, a move is either valid (reward = 1) or it overlaps by a pixel (reward = -100). This sparse, binary feedback loop makes it nearly impossible for an agent to “learn” a gradient. It doesn’t know*how*to fix the overlap, just that it failed.## The Solution: Simulated Annealing (on Steroids)
The “Secret Sauce” currently dominating the leaderboard is**Simulated Annealing (SA)**combined with**Lattice Generation**.
Instead of training a model to*predict*the position, teams are writing physics engines that*shake*the box.
* **High Temperature:**Randomly spin and throw trees into the box (Explorer Phase).
* **Low Temperature:**Jiggle the trees by microscopic amounts to resolve collisions (Exploiter Phase).
The best solutions right now use a “Hybrid” strategy:
* **N < 58:**Use Simulated Annealing to find unstructured, chaotic packings.
* **N > 58:**Switch to “Crystalline Packing” (regular geometric lattices) which is mathematically superior for large numbers.## The Twist: How LLMs are Actually Helping
If RL is dead, where is the AI?
Top competitors aren’t using LLMs to*solve*the puzzle; they are using LLMs to**write the solver**.
Python is too slow for 10 billion annealing steps. The meta this year is to prompt Gemini 3 or Claude to:
“Rewrite this Python overlap-check function in Rust/C++ with AVX2 vectorization.”
We are seeing “Hybrid” workflows where the**Human**defines the heuristics, the**LLM**writes the highly optimized C++ kernels, and**Simulated Annealing**does the heavy lifting.
## The Starter Code: A Simple Annealer
If you want to jump in before the January deadline, don’t start with PyTorch. Start here.
Here is a conceptual snippet for a “Perturbation” mover —the heart of any good annealing solution.
```
import numpy as np
import math
def anneal(layout, max\_temps=10000):
# layout: Array of [x, y, rotation] for N trees
current\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
temperature = 1.0
cooling\_rate = 0.9995
for i in range(max\_temps):
# 1. Propose a Move (The "Shake")
# We only move ONE tree slightly to save compute
idx = np.random.randint(0, len(layout))
original\_pos = layout[idx].copy()
# Perturb: Move x/y by small amount, rotate slightly
layout[idx][0] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][1] += np.random.normal(0, temperature)
layout[idx][2] += np.random.normal(0, temperature \* 10) # Rotate
# 2. Check Constraints (The "Wall")
if check\_overlap(layout):
# Revert immediately if invalid
layout[idx] = original\_pos
continue
# 3. Acceptance Criteria (Metropolis-Hastings)
new\_score = calculate\_area(layout)
delta = new\_score - current\_score
# If better, accept. If worse, accept with prob based on Temp.
if delta < 0 or math.exp(-delta / temperature) > np.random.rand():
current\_score = new\_score
else:
layout[idx] = original\_pos # Revert
# Cool down
temperature \*= cooling\_rate
return layout, current\_score
# Pro Tip: Ask an LLM to convert ''check\_overlap'' to Cython for 100x speed.
```
The competition ends**January 30, 2026**. You have 40 days. Put down the Neural Network and pick up a physics textbook.
*(****Discussion:****Are you using a Lattice approach or pure Annealing for N=200? Let’s discuss strategy in the comments!)*

# Two-dimensional irregular packing problems: A review

[Baosu Guo](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1790185) 1,2[Yu Zhang](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1800049) 1Jingwen Hu1Jinrui Li1Fenghe Wu1,2[Qingjin Peng](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1154896) 3[Quan Zhang](https://loop.frontiersin.org/people/1180007) 4\*

- 1School of Mechanical Engineering, Yanshan University, Qinhuangdao, China
- 2Heavy-duty Intelligent Manufacturing Equipment Innovation Center of Hebei Province, Qinhuangdao, China
- 3Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, MB, Canada
- 4School of Mechatronic Engineering and Automation, Shanghai University, Shanghai, China

Two-dimensional (2D) irregular packing problems are widespread in manufacturing industries such as shipbuilding, metalworking, automotive production, aerospace, clothing and furniture manufacturing. Research on 2D irregular packing problems is essential for improving material utilization and industrial automation. Much research has been conducted on this problem with significant research results and certain algorithms. The work has made important contributions to solving practical problems. This paper reviews recent advances in the domain of 2D irregular packing problems based on a variety of research papers. We first introduce the basic concept and research background of 2D irregular packing problems and then summarize algorithms and strategies that have been proposed for the problems in recent years. Conclusion summarize development trends and research hotspots of typical 2D irregular shape packing problems. We hope that this review could provide guidance for researchers in the field of 2D irregular packing.

## 1 Introduction

Two-dimensional (2D) irregular packing problems are widespread in industries such as machinery manufacturing, aviation, shipbuilding, automobile manufacturing, clothing and furniture manufacturing. An efficient 2D irregular packing algorithm can effectively improve material utilization and reduce processing costs. The reduction in material consumption will also have a beneficial impact on the environment ( [Ke et al., 2020](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B76)). Therefore, research of the packing problem is of great significance for technology and social interest.

The 2D packing problem is a type of combinatorial optimization problems to locate parts with different shapes compactly in one or more master sheet material to minimize the occupied space or maximize the utilization of the material. The 2D packing problem is currently recognized as a NP problem, which is mainly solved by heuristic algorithms. In recent years, many scholars have conducted research on 2D irregular packing problems with a verity of solutions.

There exists a number of review articles on packing and cutting problems. We have summarized the main review literature in the field of 2D packing and cutting as shown in [Table 1](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#T1). Brown ( [Brown, 1971](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B17)) introduced an optimum packing and depletion problem with optimization of space and resource usage. Harvey ( [Salkin and De Kluyver, 1975](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B116)) surveyed the application of mathematical optimization models such as linear programming to the knapsack problem. Bruce ( [Golden, 1976](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B50)) surveyed various approaches to the cutting stock problem. Hinxman ( [Hinxman, 1980](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B65)) surveyed the trim-loss and assortment problems, this research paid more attention to cutting and packaging problems in practical applications, and did not mention much about theoretical methods. Garey and Coffman ( [Garey and Johnson, 1981](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B47); [Coffman et al., 1984](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B27)) surveyed the approximation algorithms for bin packing problems. Israni ( [Israni and Sanders, 1982](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B72)) reviewed the 2D cutting stock problem including almost all 2D packaging problems. The author also proposed a rectangular layout method. Sarin ( [Sarin, 1983](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B118)) reviewed methodologies and literature to solve 2D stock cutting problems and introduced an interactive optimization procedure for a general 2D stock cutting problem. Dyckhoff ( [Dyckhoff et al., 1985](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B38)) described a trim loss and related problems and categorized them briefly. Dudziński ( [Dudziński and Walukiewicz, 1987](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B36)) summarized the exact methods for knapsack problems, such as linear programming. Matthias ( [Rode and Rosenberg, 1987](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B114)) analyzed the algorithm for the trim-loss problems. Haessler ( [Haessler and Sweeney, 1991](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B59)) reviewed the solution process of cutting stock problems, including placement algorithm and sequence optimization algorithm. Dowsland ( [Dowsland and Dowsland, 1992](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B34)) reviewed the application of operations research methods to the packing problem and summarized some exact heuristics. Sweeney ( [Sweeney and Paternoster, 1992](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B128)) categorized cutting and packing problems and made application-oriented research records. Cheng ( [Cheng et al., 1994](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B22)) discussed 2D cutting stock problems and their application cases including the pallet loading problem and VLSI placement problem. With the gradual deepening of research on 2D layout problems, typology becomes a common research topic. 2D regular and irregular layout problems are clearly distinguished in practical applications and theoretical methods. Dowsland ( [Dowsland and Dowsland, 1995](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B29)) gave a special review of the 2D irregular nesting problem for the first time. Mavridou ( [Mavridou and Pardalos, 1997](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B98)) summarized applications of the genetic algorithm and simulated annealing algorithm in the optimization of facility layout problems. Dyckhoff ( [Dyckhoff, 1990](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B37)) made a typology of the cutting and packing problems in detail, and Wäscher ( [Wäscher et al., 2007](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B135)) improved the typology later. Hopper ( [Hopper and Turton, 1999](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B67); [Hopper and Turton, 2001a](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B68); [Hopper and Turton, 2001b](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B69)) investigated the application of meta-heuristic and heuristic algorithms in 2D and 3D packing problems. Lodi ( [Lodi et al., 2002a](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B90); [Lodi et al., 2002b](https://www.frontiersin.org/www.frontiersin.org#B91)) reviewed algorithms proposed in the 1990s of 2D packing problems. results.text:
Abstract

This paper presents a novel artificial intelligence (AI)-driven approach to two-dimensional irregular pattern packing by integrating advanced image processing with an enhanced Genetic Algorithm (GA). From meta-heuristic optimization methods, the GA is adapted to improve material utilization and the compactness of pattern placement. We introduce a simple and effective overlap detection technique based on pixel counting, alongside a two-dimensional packing optimization strategy guided by each pattern's expanded area. These innovations make the placement process more flexible and precise, leading to improved overall packing efficiency. The results demonstrate that the refined GA combined with the expanded-area-based optimization strategy significantly enhances material utilization and pattern packing performance. This research not only addresses key challenges in irregular packing through an AI-based approach but also establishes a new benchmark for future optimization techniques in this domain.

Introduction

Two-dimensional irregular packing problems have received considerable attention due to their wide applicability across industries such as manufacturing, logistics, and design (Gomes, 2013; Ma et al., 2018; Stoyan et al., 2016). The corresponding problems involve arranging irregularly shaped objects within a limited space in an efficient way to improve material utilization. The special challenges of the process arise due to the irregularities of shapes and the constraints involved.

In recent years, the advancements in algorithms and computational techniques have significantly pushed the boundaries of research in this area by offering innovative insights and solutions, including mathematical and advanced self-learning models (Fang et al., 2021, 2023; Gomes, 2013; Chen et al., 2022; Hu et al., 2018).

The genesis of contemporary approaches to irregular packing problems was proposed by Gomes and Oliveira (2006), who introduced a pioneering hybrid algorithm that combined simulated annealing with linear programming. Their approach significantly advanced the optimization of placement for irregular shaped parts, demonstrating the potential of combining metaheuristics with linear models for local optimization. The realm of guillotine cuts, a prevalent challenge in industries such as glass cutting, was addressed by Han et al. (2013) through the application of one-stage and two-stage strategies, underscoring the efficiency of direct guillotine-cutting layouts from irregular shapes without necessitating initial rectangle encasement.

Further exploration into the optimization of two-dimensional irregular bin packing problems was presented by Martinez-Sykora et al. (2017), who proposed constructive algorithms that leveraged integer programming for piece assignment and mixed integer programming for placement within bins. The incorporation of free rotation of pieces by Abeysooriya et al. (2018) marked a significant progress, allowing for a more flexible approach for packing irregular shapes and demonstrating the effectiveness of alternative placement criteria over the common bottom-left criteria.

The application of genetic algorithms to enhance traditional methods was explored by Wong et al. (2009), offering a hybrid methodology that improved the efficiency of packing processes for irregular-shaped parts. Gomes (2013) made significant contributions to the area by highlighting the computational geometry's role in enhancing nesting algorithms for irregular packing problems, emphasizing the requirement for advanced geometric tools in optimizing solutions.

In the realm of automated packing solutions, Bouganis and Shanahan (2007) presented a vision-based intelligent technique that utilized computer vision and artificial intelligence to pack 2D irregular shapes efficiently, showcasing significant advancements in computational efficiency and solution quality. The optimization of shape rotation angles for better packing outcomes was further refined by Guo et al. (2018) based on the application of Principal Component Analysis (PCA), demonstrating improved packing density. Liu et al. (2023) developed a hybrid approach combining genetic algorithm and linear programming to optimize two-dimensional irregular packing, significantly enhancing material utilization and efficiency. Cai et al. (2023) tackled the 2-D irregular bin packing issue by developing heuristics that accommodate specific degrees of rotation for packing irregular shapes efficiently. Their novel approach optimized the packing strategy by accounting for the material's texture constraints, delivering effective solutions to maximize utilization across various industries.

The extension of the orbital sliding method to handle arcs in irregular packing was discussed by Burke et al. (2010), improving the accuracy of no-fit polygon calculations and thus the efficiency of packing solutions. Terashima-Marín et al. (2010) introduced a GA-based model for generating hyper-heuristics, showcasing the potential of hyper-heuristics in outperforming individual heuristics for both regular and irregular shapes. The adaptation of the Djang and Finch heuristic for two-dimensional irregular bin packing problems by López-Camacho et al. (2013) and the introduction of a beam search approach by Bennell and Song (2010) further contributed to the advancement of efficient packing solutions.

Transitioning towards self-learning models, Zhang et al. (2021) introduced a model utilizing deep reinforcement learning and self-attention mechanisms, marking a significant advancement in the application of machine learning to bin packing problems. The learning-assisted method for packing 2D irregular shapes, focusing on UV patches from 3D models by Yang et al. (2023). Fang et al. (2023) proposed a hybrid reinforcement learning algorithm tailored for 2D irregular packing problems. This algorithm represents a pioneering attempt to combine machine learning strategies with traditional packing methodologies, highlighting the expanding scope of machine learning applications in optimizing raw material utilization.

Leao et al. (2020) and Guo et al. # Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1
[](#santa-2025---christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
This repository contains my approach for the[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge](https://www.kaggle.com/competitions/santa-2025)on Kaggle.
## Overview
[](#overview)
The objective of this challenge is to optimally pack rotatable Christmas trees (polygonal shapes) into the smallest possible square, minimizing the bounding box area for each value of N (number of trees from 1 to 200). The final solution is evaluated by an ensemble score that combines all cases.
**Notebook Link**:[Santa 2025 - Christmas Tree Packing Challenge V1](https://www.kaggle.com/code/adityapawar327/santa-2025-christmas-tree-packing-challenge-v1)
**Public Score**: 85.92
## Table of Contents
[](#table-of-contents)
* Library Imports and Environment Setup
* Global Configuration and Precision Settings
* ChristmasTree Class Definition
* Utility Functions (Scoring/Collision)
* Simulated Annealing Algorithm (N < 20)
* Grid Search Algorithm (N >= 20)
* Hybrid & Ensemble Solvers
* Main Computation Loop (N = 1 to 200)
* Submission Formatting and Export
## Methodology
[](#methodology)
* **Small N (< 20):**Uses Simulated Annealing for efficient search in small configuration spaces.
* **Large N (>= 20):**Uses a tailored Grid Search for tractable solution space exploration.
* **Hybrid/Ensemble:**Runs multiple seeds and chooses the best solution for each N.
* **Collision Detection:**Employs Shapely geometry operations to prevent tree overlap.
* **Performance:**Code leverages parallelization (`ProcessPoolExecutor`) and high-precision (Decimal) arithmetic.
## Usage
[](#usage)
1. Install dependencies:
* `shapely`,`numpy`,`pandas`,`matplotlib`,`tqdm`
* Run the notebook or script sequentially to output results and save a`submission.csv`.
* Check the score on important N cases (e.g., 1, 10, 25, 50, 100, 150, 200).
## Output
[](#output)
* The notebook prints key logs during computation.
* A`submission.csv`is generated with columns:`id`,`x`,`y`,`deg`(example row:`001\_0, s-9.146226, s-0.12832, s-224.999647`).
